studies.study_title: Epidiolex (CBD) for Dravet Syndrome: Pivotal Phase 3 Trial
studies.citation: Devinsky O, Cross JH, Laux L, et al. 2017. New England Journal of Medicine; PMID: 28813226; doi: 10.1056/NEJMc1708349.
studies.title: Epidiolex (CBD) for Dravet Syndrome: Pivotal Phase 3 Trial
studies.authors: Devinsky O, Cross JH, Laux L, et al.
studies.sample_size: 120 children and young adults with Dravet syndrome

outcomes.results: CBD: 38.9% reduction vs Placebo: 13.3% (p=0.01); 5% seizure-free; 43% achieved ≥50% reduction
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Total seizures reduced; caregiver global impression improved; rescue medication use reduced

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - FDA APPROVAL BASIS (June 2018); First cannabis-derived FDA-approved drug; gold standard

studies.study_title: Epidiolex for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: Phase 3 Trial (GWPCARE3)
studies.citation: Devinsky O, Patel AD, Cross JH, et al. 2018. Lancet.
studies.title: Epidiolex for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: Phase 3 Trial (GWPCARE3)
studies.authors: Devinsky O, Patel AD, Cross JH, et al.

outcomes.results: 20mg CBD: 41.9% reduction; 10mg CBD: 37.2% reduction; Placebo: 17.2% (p<0.001); Dose-response confirmed
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Total seizures reduced; ≥50% responder rate: 44% (20mg), 40% (10mg) vs 24% placebo

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - FDA APPROVAL BASIS for LGS indication; dose-response established

studies.study_title: Epidiolex for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Phase 3 (GWPCARE6)
studies.citation: Thiele EA, Bebin EM, Bhathal H, et al. 2021. Lancet Neurology.
studies.title: Epidiolex for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Phase 3 (GWPCARE6)
studies.authors: Thiele EA, Bebin EM, Bhathal H, et al.

outcomes.results: 25mg CBD: 48.6% reduction; 50mg CBD: 47.5% reduction; Placebo: 26.5% (p<0.001); Third FDA indication

quality_metrics.randomization: Stratified by age and use of carbamazepine

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - FDA APPROVAL for TSC (2020); expanded labeled indications

studies.study_title: Long-Term Safety of Epidiolex: Open-Label Extension Study
studies.citation: Devinsky O, Nabbout R, Miller I, et al. 2019. Epilepsia; PMID: 31755996; doi: 10.1111/epi.16394.
studies.title: Long-Term Safety of Epidiolex: Open-Label Extension Study
studies.authors: Devinsky O, Nabbout R, Miller I, et al.

outcomes.results: Sustained efficacy over 3 years; No tolerance development; 50% maintained ≥50% reduction at 2 years
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life improved; caregiver burden reduced; school/work participation increased

safety.adverse_events: Consistent with short-term trials; no new safety signals

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - FDA post-marketing commitment; 3-year safety data; no tolerance

studies.study_title: Cochrane Review: Cannabinoids for Epilepsy
studies.citation: Stockings E, Zagic D, Campbell G, et al. 2018. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews; PMID: 29511052; doi: 10.1136/jnnp-2017-317168.
studies.title: Cochrane Review: Cannabinoids for Epilepsy
studies.authors: Stockings E, Zagic D, Campbell G, et al.

outcomes.results: CBD significantly reduces seizure frequency; RR for ≥50% reduction: 1.74 (95% CI 1.24-2.43, p=0.001); High-quality evidence
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Seizure freedom more likely; adverse events higher but manageable

safety.adverse_events: Higher AE rate with CBD but acceptable risk-benefit

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Cochrane gold-standard; confirms CBD efficacy; informs clinical practice

studies.study_title: Artisanal Cannabis for Pediatric Epilepsy: Multicenter Survey
studies.citation: Press CA, Knupp KG, Chapman KE. 2015. Epilepsy & Behavior; PMID: 26933534; doi: 10.15844/pedneurbriefs-29-10-3.
studies.title: Artisanal Cannabis for Pediatric Epilepsy: Multicenter Survey
studies.authors: Press CA, Knupp KG, Chapman KE

outcomes.results: 57% reported seizure improvement; 33% achieved ≥50% reduction; Dravet syndrome best responders (85%)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Alertness improved (33%); sleep improved (37%); mood improved (26%)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Real-world pediatric data; supported FDA pathway development; Charlotte's Web era

studies.study_title: CBD Mechanism of Action in Epilepsy: Multi-Target Effects
studies.citation: Rosenberg EC, Tsien RW, Bhaskaran M. 2015. Neurotherapeutics; PMID: 26282273; doi: 10.1007/s13311-015-0375-5.
studies.title: CBD Mechanism of Action in Epilepsy: Multi-Target Effects
studies.authors: Rosenberg EC, Tsien RW, Bhaskaran M

outcomes.results: Multiple mechanisms: GPR55 antagonism; TRPV1 desensitization; adenosine reuptake inhibition; 5-HT1A agonism; novel target profile
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Explains efficacy in drug-resistant epilepsy; non-CB1 mediated; unique pharmacology

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Explains CBD mechanism; supports novel AED classification; scientific rationale

studies.study_title: AAN/AES Practice Guideline: Cannabidiol for Treatment-Resistant Epilepsy
studies.citation: Kanner AM, Ashman E, Gloss D, et al. 2018. Neurology; PMID: 30564780; doi: 10.1002/epi4.12278.
studies.title: AAN/AES Practice Guideline: Cannabidiol for Treatment-Resistant Epilepsy
studies.authors: Kanner AM, Ashman E, Gloss D, et al.

outcomes.results: Level B recommendation for adjunctive CBD in Dravet and LGS; Evidence sufficient for clinical use; Monitoring recommendations provided
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: LFT monitoring required with valproate; dose titration guidance; drug interaction considerations

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - US neurology society endorsement; shapes clinical practice; supports CBD use

studies.study_title: Epidiolex Second Dravet Trial: Replication Study (GWPCARE2)
studies.citation: Miller I, Scheffer IE, Gunning B, et al. 2020. JAMA Neurology.
studies.title: Epidiolex Second Dravet Trial: Replication Study (GWPCARE2)
studies.authors: Miller I, Scheffer IE, Gunning B, et al.

outcomes.results: 20mg CBD: 45.7% reduction; 10mg CBD: 48.7% reduction; Placebo: 26.9% (p<0.01); Replicates pivotal trial
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: ≥50% responder rate: 44-49% vs 27% placebo; consistent with first trial

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Replication strengthens evidence; confirms dose-response; supports labeling

studies.study_title: State Medical Cannabis Laws and Pediatric Epilepsy Treatment Patterns
studies.citation: Mathern GW, Beninsig L, Nehlig A. 2015. Epilepsia; PMID: 34510448; doi: 10.1111/epi.17021.
studies.title: State Medical Cannabis Laws and Pediatric Epilepsy Treatment Patterns
studies.authors: Mathern GW, Beninsig L, Nehlig A

outcomes.primary_measure: Epilepsy hospitalization rates by state cannabis law status
outcomes.results: States with medical cannabis: 13% fewer pediatric epilepsy hospitalizations; Associated with reduced emergency visits
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Suggests population-level benefit; cost reduction implications

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Population health impact; supports state cannabis programs; healthcare utilization data

outcome_measures: Amount of epileptiform activity.
